message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute angle-closure glaucoma, which is a medical emergency that can lead to permanent vision loss. Acetazolamide is the most appropriate initial treatment as it decreases intraocular pressure, which can help prevent further damage. Retinal photocoagulation and topical epinephrine are not appropriate initial treatments for this condition. Topical prednisolone may be useful for certain eye conditions, but it is not appropriate for acute angle-closure glaucoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma, which is an emergency. The initial treatment should be to reduce intraocular pressure, which is achieved by acetazolamide. None of the other treatments listed will effectively reduce intraocular pressure in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma, which is a medical emergency. Acetazolamide is the initial treatment of choice as it reduces intraocular pressure. Retinal photocoagulation, topical epinephrine, and topical prednisolone are not appropriate initial treatments for acute angle-closure glaucoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest acute angle-closure glaucoma. The initial treatment should be aimed at reducing the intraocular pressure, which can be done with intravenous acetazolamide. Retinal photocoagulation is not appropriate for acute angle-closure glaucoma. Topical epinephrine and topical prednisolone are not first-line treatments for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest acute angle-closure glaucoma, which is a medical emergency. Intravenous acetazolamide reduces intraocular pressure and is the most appropriate initial treatment. Retinal photocoagulation is not indicated in this case, and topical epinephrine and prednisolone are not an appropriate initial treatment for acute angle-closure glaucoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest acute angle-closure glaucoma, which is a medical emergency. Intravenous acetazolamide is the most appropriate initial treatment to lower intraocular pressure and prevent optic nerve damage. Retinal photocoagulation is used for diabetic retinopathy, topical epinephrine can worsen angle-closure glaucoma, and topical prednisolone is used for inflammation, which is not the cause of the patient's symptoms.

Intravenous acetazolamide is the most appropriate initial treatment to decrease intraocular pressure and prevent further damage to the eye. Retinal photocoagulation, topical epinephrine, and topical prednisolone are not indicated in the initial management of acute angle-closure glaucoma.

The most appropriate initial treatment is Intravenous acetazolamide to decrease intraocular pressure. Retinal photocoagulation, topical epinephrine, and topical prednisolone are not appropriate initial treatments for acute angle-closure glaucoma.
